A detection mechanism based on abnormal changes in the leader’s position is used to identify the presence of GPS attacks, and a trajectory correction method is applied to gradually recover the leader’s position. To handle unknown system dynamics, the paper employs a fuzzy logic system to approximate nonlinear terms and compensate for disturbances through adaptive parameter updates. For safety, an improved artificial potential field (APF) method is designed to generate repulsive forces for collision avoidance between USVs and obstacle avoidance in the environment, while ensuring that USVs can still reach the target position even when obstacles are nearby. These APF-based forces are integrated into the formation control law together with formation tracking errors and fuzzy compensation terms. The authors conduct a Lyapunov-based stability analysis to prove that the closed-loop multi-USV system remains stable under GPS attacks and that formation tracking errors are uniformly ultimately bounded. Simulation results involving multiple USVs, static obstacles, and injected GPS spoofing attacks demonstrate that the proposed control strategy allows the USVs to maintain formation, avoid collisions and obstacles, recover from GPS spoofing, and operate within actuator saturation limits.

references.name: Throughput Maximization for USV-Enabled Underwater Wireless Networks Under jamming Attack
references.cite: H. Zhang et al., “Throughput Maximization for USV-Enabled Underwater Wireless Networks Under jamming Attack,” IEEE Sens. J., vol. 24, no. 14, pp. 21987–21996, 2024, doi: 10.1109/JSEN.2023.3325552.
references.description:
This paper studies underwater wireless networks (UWNs) supported by an unmanned surface vehicle (USV) under malicious jamming attacks. Underwater communication relies on acoustic signals, which are open, noisy, bandwidth-limited, and highly vulnerable to jamming. The authors consider a scenario where a source node (SN) communicates with a destination node (DN) via a relay USV (R-USV) because direct communication is unavailable, while a jammer interferes with both communication links. The objective is to maximize the achievable end-to-end throughput despite jamming. 
 The system consists of four nodes: SN, DN, R-USV, and jammer. The USV moves on the water surface over a finite time divided into discrete time slots. Its motion is constrained by minimum and maximum sailing speeds, ocean current effects, and a maximum steering angle for safe navigation. The USV’s transmit power is limited by average and peak power constraints. Underwater acoustic channel loss is modelled using geometric spreading loss and absorption loss, which depend on distance, frequency, and propagation conditions. Using Shannon’s capacity formula, the achievable throughput of each link is computed while accounting for jamming power and noise. 
 An information causality constraint is imposed so the USV can only forward data it has received within the same time slot. Therefore, the end-to-end throughput at each time slot is defined as the minimum of the SN–USV and USV–DN throughputs. The overall problem is to maximize the sum of these per-slot throughputs while satisfying trajectory, power, steering, and causality constraints. 
 To solve this complex problem, the authors formulate it as a Markov decision process (MDP) and apply deep reinforcement learning (DRL). The USV is the learning agent. The state includes the USV position, transmit power, and link throughputs; the action includes changes in sailing direction and transmit power. A reward function encourages higher throughput while penalising constraint violations and guiding the USV toward its destination. 
 The paper proposes a Double Deep Q-Network (D2QN)-based joint trajectory and power optimization algorithm (D2QN-JTP). Compared with a standard Deep Q-Network (DQN), D2QN reduces Q-value overestimation by separating action selection and value evaluation. Simulation results show that D2QN-JTP achieves more stable learning, higher cumulative rewards, and higher achievable throughput than DQN under different jamming intensities and operation times. The optimized USV adapts both its trajectory and transmit power to reduce jamming impact. 
 The paper concludes that joint trajectory and power optimization using deep reinforcement learning significantly improves the anti-jamming performance and throughput of USV-enabled underwater wireless networks. Future work suggests extending the approach to multiple cooperative USVs.

references.name: Network-Based Modeling and Sampling Guaranteed Cost Control for Unmanned Surface Vehicle Systems Under Stochastic Cyber-Attacks
references.cite: K. Ding, Q. Zhu, and S. Member, “Network-Based Modeling and Sampling Guaranteed Cost Control for Unmanned Surface Vehicle Systems Under Stochastic Cyber-Attacks,” IEEE Trans. Intell. Transp. Syst., vol. 25, no. 6, pp. 6173–6185, 2024, doi: 10.1109/TITS.2023.3348841.
references.description:
This paper studies guaranteed cost output sampling control for unmanned surface vehicles operating over communication networks under stochastic cyber-attacks. The authors model cyber-attacks as stochastic disturbances using white noise, which randomly affect the transmission of measurement and control signals. A network-based USV model is developed where only finite sampled output information is available to the controller.

To ensure stability and performance, the paper proposes an output point-sampling control strategy and constructs a sampling-time-dependent Lyapunov function. This Lyapunov function explicitly captures information at sampling instants and within sampling intervals, allowing the system to be analysed under mean-square exponential stability. Based on this formulation, sufficient conditions are derived to guarantee an upper bound on a quadratic cost function.

The guaranteed cost control problem is formulated as a set of linear matrix inequalities, and a suboptimal controller design method is provided to minimise the upper bound of the control cost. Simulation results using a USV model under different operating speeds show that the proposed method stabilises the system under stochastic cyber-attacks while reducing control effort and communication burden.

references.name: Event-Based Distributed Secure Control of Unmanned Surface Vehicles with DoS Attacks
references.cite: C. Liu, B. Jiang, X. Wang, Y. Zhang, and S. Xie, “Event-Based Distributed Secure Control of Unmanned Surface Vehicles with DoS Attacks,” IEEE Trans. Syst. Man, Cybern. Syst., vol. 54, no. 4, pp. 2159–2170, 2024, doi: 10.1109/TSMC.2023.3341158.
references.description: This paper proposes an event-based distributed secure control framework for networked unmanned surface vehicles operating under combined cyber and physical threats. The study considers unified abrupt and incipient rudder angle actuator faults, wave-induced disturbances, and aperiodic Denial-of-Service (DoS) attacks that intermittently block inter-vehicle communication. A decentralized unknown input observer is designed to estimate both vehicle states and actuator faults without requiring prior bounds on disturbances. Based on these estimates, an event-triggered distributed control law is developed, which switches between cooperative control during DoS dormancy and purely local control during DoS activation. Stability analysis based on Lyapunov methods establishes explicit conditions on DoS attack frequency and average dwelling time to guarantee exponential consensus of multiple USVs while avoiding Zeno behavior.

references.name: Collision-Free Distributed Adaptive Resilient Formation Control for Underactuated USVs Subject to Intermittent Actuator Faults and Denial-of-Service Attacks
references.cite: X. Wu, G. Zong, H. Wang, B. Niu, and X. Zhao, “Collision-Free Distributed Adaptive Resilient Formation Control for Underactuated USVs Subject to Intermittent Actuator Faults and Denial-of-Service Attacks,” IEEE Trans. Veh. Technol., vol. 74, no. 9, pp. 13606–13617, 2025, doi: 10.1109/TVT.2025.3565820.
references.description:
This paper investigates collision-free distributed formation control for underactuated unmanned surface vehicles (USVs) under intermittent actuator faults and Denial-of-Service (DoS) attacks. The USVs are subject to unknown nonlinear dynamics and limited actuation, where only surge and yaw are directly controlled. To address these challenges, fuzzy logic systems are used to approximate unknown dynamics, and an adaptive fault-tolerant controller is designed to compensate for intermittent actuator faults. 
A resilient distributed formation estimator is developed to maintain formation tracking during DoS attacks, when communication among USVs and the leader is temporarily unavailable. An artificial potential field with continuous partial derivatives is integrated into the estimator to guarantee collision avoidance without introducing abrupt control actions. In addition, a simple prescribed performance control scheme is proposed to ensure that formation tracking errors converge to a predefined accuracy within a user-specified settling time. Lyapunov-based analysis proves closed-loop stability, and simulation results confirm effective formation tracking, fault tolerance, and collision avoidance under combined cyber and physical attacks.

references.name: An Attack on an Integrated Navigation System
references.cite: M. S. Lund, O. S. Hareide, and Ø. Jøsok, “An Attack on an Integrated Navigation System,” Necesse, vol. 3, no. 2, pp. 149–163, 2018, doi: 10.21339/2464-353x.3.2.149.
references.description:
This paper presents a proof-of-concept cyber attack against an Integrated Navigation System (INS) used on modern vessels. An INS is a networked navigation system that integrates multiple sensors, such as the Global Positioning System (GPS), gyrocompass, Automatic Identification System (AIS), and others, and distributes this data to Electronic Chart Display and Information Systems (ECDIS) running on operator stations. ECDIS is the software used by operators to visualise vessel position, heading, and surrounding traffic on electronic nautical charts. The study demonstrates that it is possible to manipulate navigation data inside the internal network of the vessel, without attacking satellite GPS signals directly. 
 The authors design an attack that compromises an ECDIS operator station running on Windows. The core idea is to install malware that acts as a man-in-the-middle between the navigation software and incoming sensor data. Instead of spoofing GPS radio signals, the malware intercepts network messages sent from the Sensor Integrator (SINT), which is the component that collects sensor data and broadcasts it to operator stations. These messages are sent using UDP (User Datagram Protocol) and follow the NMEA 0183 standard, which is a plaintext maritime data format for navigation information. Because the messages are unencrypted and unauthenticated, the malware can modify GPS coordinates before they are displayed on the chart. 
 The attack is structured using the intrusion kill chain model, which includes reconnaissance, weaponisation, delivery, exploitation, installation, command and control, and actions on objectives. During reconnaissance, the authors capture network traffic directly from the INS by connecting a laptop to the internal switch and analysing packets with Wireshark. They discover that the ECDIS software communicates using Windows Sockets (Winsock) and that all devices use static IP addresses. This allows the attackers to fully understand message formats, port numbers, and sensor data flows. 
 For weaponisation, the attackers create a malicious replacement Winsock dynamic-link library (DLL). A DLL is a shared code library used by Windows applications. By exploiting DLL search-order hijacking, the fake DLL is loaded instead of the legitimate one, allowing the malware to intercept incoming network traffic. When the malware detects GPS NMEA sentences (for example, GPGGA messages), it modifies latitude and longitude values and recalculates the checksum so that the ECDIS software accepts the manipulated data. In addition to position manipulation, the malware also includes a script that can deliberately crash the operator station by terminating a critical Windows process, causing a blue screen of death (BSOD). 
 Delivery of the malware assumes the system is air-gapped, meaning it has no Internet connection. Therefore, the authors use a USB Human Interface Device (HID) attack. A programmable microcontroller is configured to behave like a keyboard and mouse. When inserted into a USB port, it automatically types commands, disables ECDIS keyboard restrictions using a maintenance password, opens a command prompt, copies malware from an attached USB storage device, and installs it. The attack does not exploit software vulnerabilities but relies on physical access, administrator-level user accounts, and weak operational security practices. 
 Once installed, the malware does not require external command-and-control communication. Instead, it uses navigation data itself as a trigger mechanism. The malware activates when the vessel enters predefined geographic regions. Within these regions, it gradually introduces positional drift by adding small deviations to each GPS update, causing the displayed vessel position to slowly diverge from reality. In another trigger region, the malware forces the operator station to crash. This makes the attack stealthy, as changes appear gradual and context-dependent. 
 The attack is experimentally demonstrated on a real vessel operated by the Royal Norwegian Navy. During sea trials, one operator station is infected while another remains clean, allowing direct comparison. The results show visible divergence between true vessel position and manipulated ECDIS output, with position errors accumulating over time. The authors confirm that the attack works without modifying the INS configuration beforehand and without exploiting known software vulnerabilities. 
 The paper also discusses feasibility and countermeasures. The attack succeeds mainly because of plaintext navigation data, lack of integrity protection, excessive user privileges, and reliance on air-gapping. Potential mitigations include restricting user privileges, disabling scripting engines, deploying integrity checks on navigation data, cryptographic signing of sensor messages, and better physical security. Redundancy mechanisms, such as dual networks and multiple sensors, can raise alarms but do not fully prevent manipulation unless all data paths are protected. 
 The paper shows that internal navigation data manipulation is a realistic and practical threat to maritime systems. Although demonstrated on a conventional vessel, the attack principles directly apply to USVs, which rely even more heavily on automated navigation and sensor fusion. The work highlights that navigation cyber attacks do not require sophisticated exploits and can be executed with modest resources if system design and operational security are weak.

references.name: Novel security models, metrics and security assessment for maritime vessel networks
references.cite: S. Y. Enoch, J. S. Lee, and D. S. Kim, “Novel security models, metrics and security assessment for maritime vessel networks,” Comput. Networks, vol. 189, no. October 2020, p. 107934, 2021, doi: 10.1016/j.comnet.2021.107934.
references.description: This paper presents a comprehensive security modelling and assessment approach for modern maritime vessel networks, including unmanned and autonomous surface vessels (USVs). The authors describe how vessel systems such as navigation (ECDIS), engine control, cargo management, bridge control, and administrative systems are interconnected and often linked to shore networks through permanent connections (e.g., satellite VSAT) or temporary wireless links, which significantly increases the cyber-attack surface. To address the lack of quantitative cybersecurity analysis for vessel networks, the paper proposes the Maritime Vessel Hierarchical Attack Representation Model (MV-HARM), a formal graphical security model that captures vessel systems, their vulnerabilities, network reachability, and multi-stage attack paths. MV-HARM is structured as a two-layer model, where the upper layer represents system connectivity with probabilistic weights reflecting temporal and permanent connections, and the lower layer represents system vulnerabilities using attack trees. The model supports analysing attacks targeting single or multiple vessel functions through logical AND/OR attack goals. To quantify security, the paper defines three metrics: attack success probability, system risk, and threat-specific risk based on STRIDE threat categories. Vulnerability impact and exploitability values are derived from CVSS, and threats are weighted according to their effect on vessel functions. The framework also models attacker behaviour and evaluates conventional defence strategies such as vulnerability patching, firewall rule changes, and network separation. Overall, the paper provides a structured and quantitative method to analyse attack paths, assess cybersecurity risk, and evaluate defensive measures in maritime and USV networked systems.
